column1: Databases are essential systems used to store, organize, manage, and retrieve data efficiently. They support a wide range of applications by providing key features and functionalities that enhance data management capabilities.

column2: Arranges data in structured formats such as tables (in relational databases) or flexible models like documents or graphs (in NoSQL databases).

Relational databases ensure data integrity through ACID properties (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability), while NoSQL databases often use BASE (Basically Available, Soft state, Eventually consistent) principles for availability.
Incorporates authentication, authorization, and encryption measures to protect data from unauthorized access and ensure data privacy.
Allows multiple users to access and manipulate data simultaneously while maintaining data consistency and preventing conflicts.
Supports increased loads by scaling vertically (enhancing existing hardware) in relational databases or horizontally (adding more nodes) in NoSQL databases.
Provides mechanisms to back up data and restore it if needed, ensuring data availability and durability in case of system failures.
